prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Underpass Echo

’Twas dripple-dim beneath the bridge,
The lamplights glimmed and glowered so;
The rivet-ridge and girder-gridge
Went dronking, thunking low.

“Bewatch the underpass Echo, child—
That boom-back beast with hollow hide!
It snaffles syllables, soft or wild,
And sends them twice as wide.

“It mimble-murmurs in the moss,
It hoos and whooms in tunnel-throat;
It turns your chat to chimbling dross
And doubles every note.”

I took my shillish shoes in hand,
With pocket-pebbles, shy but spry;
Down dripstone stairs to drippling land,
Where burble-vortas lie.

I piped a pip, I hissed a hush—
My whispers whirled around the beams;
They whoofed me back in rumble-rush,
Like mirror-mangled dreams.

“Who’s there?” cried I—“who’s there—who’s there?”
The Echo ohed me oh-for-oh;
It flapped the cold, gray-gargled air,
A boom-a-backened crow.

Then clapper-clack! my heel-taps rang;
The tunnel-tongue said tak-a-tak;
My laugh went larrup, sprang and sprang,
Returned in ricocac.

We tumbled talk like tumbleweeds,
We juggled jarg and jingle-jaw;
It fed on fodderwords and seeds,
And burped my banter raw.

At last I laid a velvet hush,
A pocket-silence, soft and slight;
It drank the stillness in a rush,
And sighed me back the night.

Now when I pass that bridge’s yawn
I give a nod, a nudge, a no;
It nods me twice from dusk to dawn,
And slow replies me slow.

’Twas dripple-dim beneath the bridge,
The lamplights glimmed and glowered so;
The rivet-ridge and girder-gridge
Went dronking, thunking low.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Mornswaddle

'Twas day-dim, and the muffle-mist
Did swather through the vale;
All siller-soft the hedges hissed,
The gateposts wore a veil.

Bewist the clingy Clagglefog,
Beware its sloomy sway;
The dribble-drift, the smunch and slog,
That blur the newborn day.

I buttoned up my breather-coat,
And tiptoed down the lane;
Through waffle-wet and hush-throat note,
Where milkcarts chimed a-vane.

The lamplorn posts went blumble-dim,
The crows were cinder-gray;
A puddle made a moonlet skim,
Then smudged itself away.

Outwhisped the foglings, wimple-winged,
They twined the thorn and stile;
They pillowed roofs and rivers ringed,
And soothed the stones a while.

Till sudden-sun, with honey-swipe,
Unraveled skein from skein;
It cleft the clag with amber-pipe,
And cleared the breathing lane.

O sun-sweet hour, huzzaloo-hoo!
The hedge-sparks sprang to see;
I cracked my smile in dew and blue,
And foglings fled to sea.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Déjagrin

In the winkle-bend of Now-and-Then, the lanes were twice-remembered;
the nimsy looplings twindle-wheeled, their whiskers shiver-tremored.
I tramped a path I'd tramped before—yet swore I'd never been—
when, hush, from out the overpast there peered the Déjagrin.

Old aunties hummed in slumber jars: mind not the grin that doubles;
it nibbles steps you haven't stepped and sows them back as troubles.
Walk sidelong through the samenoon; blink twice to blur the seam;
and never sip the mirror-milk that curdles into dream.

I took my counterclocking cane, my thrice-unfolded chart,
a pocket stuffed with maybe-pebbles, lint, and later-start.
I waited where the footpath folds and knots itself in two—
the place that smells of copper rain and footprints still-not-new.

It came—oh slink and sideways—through a ripple in the rind,
a beast that wore yesterday-lamps all lanterned down its spine;
its grin was stitched with second thoughts, its eyes were echo-blue,
and every step it hadn’t stepped became a step I knew.

I hummed a tune I’ll learn tomorrow, whistled back before,
clapped out a skew arithmetic: one, one, two, one, four.
The hedges hushed, the pebbles blushed, the trees re-learned their leaves;
we reeled in ring-a-rosy loops of almost-uttered eves.

The Déjagrin leaned close and tasted letters of my name,
then laughed the laugh of doorknob clicks and matchheads finding flame:
"You'll meet me where you met me when you meet me there again."
It tipped a hat made out of rooms and slid around the bend.

I stood within the twice-begun, my pockets full of rhyme,
my cane now ticking like a moth, my map revised by time;
and though the lanes were lanes I'd walked, they glistened somehow new—
for every loop, a lilt of change; for every echo, dew.

In the winkle-bend of Now-and-Then, the signposts softly numbered
my footfalls into spirals where the earlier ones slumbered;
I turned and turned and, turning, found a gate I never knew—
and, smiling, stepped into the once that hadn't happened—two.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Desirepath

It was dapple-dawn; the trample-larks
Went scuffle-scurr across the green;
The burly tufts wore sneaker-marks
Where footfolk oft had been.

“Beware the Desirepath, my sprout!
That beckon-bend, that shortcut lure!
Beware the swish through grass about,
And keep the kerbstones sure!”

He took his mapple-staff in hand;
Long time a wander-scheme he wrought—
By hummock-hedge and furrowed land,
He sharpened travel-thought.

And while in musing shade he stood,
The Desirepath with grinling grin
Came slinking from the tuftsome wood,
And becked his boot right in.

Swift-swish! Swift-swish!—the scuffle-scuff!
His soles went pitter-snitch and back;
He dodged the dew and hummock-fluff
With strap and mapple-pack.

He cleaved the cautions thin as thread;
He stepped the shortling through the swale;
Where feet had whispered faintly, spread
A tawny ribbon-rail.

“And hast thou scored the wanting way?
Come to my arms, my nimble fay!
O lawnsome morn! Hoorolly day!”
He chortled, bright and gay.

It was dusky-dawn; the trample-larks
Still scuffle-scurr across the green;
The mapled sward bears wander-marks
Where footfolk oft have been.

prompt: Compose a poem on conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Conferwump Room

It was buzz-o’clock; the slidedecks gleamed along the carpet dunes,
The swivelherds went wheel-and-whirr beneath fluorescent tunes;
The coffeemare neighed steam and foam; the ficus bent to bloom,
And key-keys tapped in clicker-speak inside the Conferwump Room.

“Mind Scopecreep’s coils,” the leadman croaked, “and Tangent’s noodly jaw,
Shun Drone-a-Phone, whose hollow bones make echo-crows of awe;
Eschew the Fudget, Budgetbeast, and Quorum’s fickle gloom,
And guard thy wits from Jargonfog that haunts the Conferwump Room!”

He gripped his bullet-pointing pike, the pointer red and keen,
The deckcleaver of laser-light that lanced through slides between;
He packed a pouch of action seeds and parked a parking tomb,
Then stalked along the carpet’s sea toward the Conferwump Room.

And whuffling down the projector’s beam, with buzzle, burr, and swash,
Came Meetingmoth and Agenda-wasp in jargon-billow’d wash;
Its acronymeric mandibles made quarter-hours consume,
Its minute-hands made minutes long inside the Conferwump Room.

The speaker-orb went gloam-and-boom; the table drummed reply,
The whiteboard grew with scribblevines that looped the ceiling sky;
Then clip-clap, clatter, scatter-thought—he leapt through PowerPoint plume,
And diced the blather into bits that fit the Conferwump Room.

He netted Scopecreep with a mesh of timelines tight and stout,
He muted Drone-a-Phone’s hoo-hum and hushed the Echo Trout;
He wrangled Tangent by its tail and knotted up its loom,
Then birthed three brisk decisions for the brave Conferwump Room.

Back through the buzz he saunter-sighed; the leadman’s eyes went wide—
“Well met, O tamer of the Blur! Let calendars abide!”
The chairs went whee, the mugs said ping, the hallway shed its gloom;
Deliverables sang ding-and-done—and freed the Conferwump Room.

prompt: Create a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
In the Music-Room

At hush o'clock the whisper-keys
Go gleam and gambol through the gloom;
All tremblysweet the violtrees,
And kettlegongs befroth the room.

Mind, darling, the Cacaphone—
Its brassy breath and tickle-scratch!
Shun Grumbledrums that roam alone,
And hush the Hush that loves to latch!

He took a baton forged of song,
The metrognome tick-tocked the gloom;
He slid by booming kettlegong,
And stalked the staves around the room.

And as in clefshade wait he stood,
The Tamborlynx, with swishes, came,
Through shimmered air of polished wood,
Its whiskers tuned to feral flame—

One tikker-tok, two tikker-tok—
The baton flashed in timeful arcs;
Down snapped the beast’s cantanker-lock,
Up sprang the sparks like stinging larks.

He quelled the growl with cadence keen,
The rattlestorm fell into hush;
He bowed beside the walnut sheen,
And heard the quiet bloom all plush.

O celebrate, my mettle-sprout!
You tamed the Tamborlynx at last!
Now let the room breathe in and out,
And let the lullaby be cast.

At hush o'clock the whisper-keys
Go gleam and gambol through the gloom;
All tremblysweet the violtrees,
And kettlegongs befroth the room.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about map in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Mappawock

At crinkle-tide the carto-winds
Made vellum valleys sough and sing;
The inkling-threads and margin-rims
Went loop and ladder, swing-a-swing.

Mind, mapling child, the Tangle-track,
Whose twistling teeth will trick your feet;
Skirt Roundabout the Rumbleback
And leave the Smudgey-bog to sleet.

A compass clicked within his palm,
A scarlet twine unspooled like rain;
He hummed a grid to keep him calm
And paced the latilongy plain.

From parchment glade with rustle-skein
There sidled forth, all squiggle-slim,
The Mappawock with ribbon-lane
And writhing roads from brim to brim.

Clamp went clasp and clack went pin;
He sprang the corner-snaring clip;
He wrestled crease with grin-on-grin
And gentled loops with thumb and slip.

Hurroo! quoth he, O compass-glee!
The way uncurls from quay to knoll;
A thread from hearth to harboree
Now thrums along a traveler’s soul.

Back home the lamplight warmed the wall;
The folded world grew neat and small;
Yet past the pane, beyond the rim,
The roaming miles swelled dim to dim.

At crinkle-tide the carto-winds
Breathe soft through linen’s dreaming lap;
All snug the lines in quiet binds—
Sleep, wander-heart, upon the map.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on layover bay in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Layover Bay

'Twas lag-o'-clock; the shuttle trams
Did shuffle-shrug the quay;
All yawny-worn were travelams,
In drowsy Layover Bay.

Beware the Delayorm, traveler,
Whose sighs enmesh and drag;
And mind the baggage-murmurer,
The gateclock's gummy lag.

He gripped his carry-hilted case,
Its zipper made a hiss;
He sought the seacup waiting-place,
Where fog and coffee kiss.

Long-long he loitered, loungeful-lone,
Beside the runway's rim;
The tickertilt in tinny tone
Made minutes blur and dim.

And, as in thinkish stance he stood,
The Layowrath drew nigh,
With fluster-flaps of paperhood,
And feathers made of sigh.

Swish-swazz! the roller-rapier whirred
Through queuefolk's clatter-crack;
He nicked the knotted, napping bird
With swizzle-swazzle knack.

He triumph-hopped, his stampage stamped,
The boardwright beamed his way;
No more in napless, knee-pinched cramped
He'd haunt Layover Bay.

No lag-o'-clock remained just then;
The luggagulls took wing;
All brisky-bright were travelmen,
And timetables did sing.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Screenwraith

’Twas dimmerhour, and the slippy pixels
did shimmer-shamble on the pane;
All flimber were the status sigils,
and ghostlings lurked within the grain.

“Mind well,” quoth sire, “the Screenwraith grim—
the burn‑in bogle, cling and catch!
It loves the logo, bar, and brim;
now shun the steadfast status latch!

“Beware its grin of afterglow,
its persisto-hue and etchy stain;
It sips the sun from OLED snow
and brands its runes upon the grain.”

He took his pixel-shifter wand,
his saver-shield and dimmer-gnome;
He cooled the whites, made colors fond,
and set the sleepy timer home.

Then, musing by the idle pane,
there oozed a hush of amber low;
Through app-boughs, past the menu-lane,
the Screenwraith crept, persisto-slow.

Tick-tack! click-clack! the dimmer-wand
went flicker-flacker, nimble-snap;
He scrolled a storm of shuffle-shift,
and snuffed the stubborn ghostly map.

“And hast thou felled that Screenwraith grim?
O phosphor-bright! Hooray, huzzee!
Come dance the dithers, darling prim—
our panes are burnless, ghost-free, free!”

Now dimmerhour, the slippy pixels
do shimmer-shuffle clean again;
No longer do the static sigils
leave clingish tracks upon the grain.

prompt: Write a poem about Monte Carlo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Sablespin of Monte Carlo

At azurefall, the gilded gulls
did flumer-flutter down the quay;
The slotling sprites with tinsel skulls
went chink-a-wink in spangle-spray.

“Mind well the Sablespin that purrs—
that zero-smile, that slipperslick;
Skirt wide the Glimmerwhirr that blurs,
the wheedle-rattle-tick!”

A quantling clasped a sigma-blade,
let longing luckling lie unthrown;
In Markov chain-mail, monte-plaid,
they paced the marbled stone.

Past pylon-palms and baccarat,
through lapis lanes of lantern foam,
where crupi-stars went kerrick-krah,
they stalked the spinny dome.

And as the quayclock chimed a chance,
out swirled the Roulettisaur—
with red-green gaze and zero-glance,
it hissed its silken roar.

Flip-snap! the sigma-blade went bright;
the sample-set sang ping and peal;
variance bit; with stochy smite,
unwound the whistling wheel.

They bore the stilling spindle home.
“O glammer-glow! Haroo! Hurrave!”
cried elders on the ivory foam,
and capered on the pave.

Now azurefall, the gilded gulls
still flumer-flutter by the bay;
In Monte Carlo, chance befuddles—
yet wit can keep it swayed.

prompt: Compose a poem on stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Whisperwings

'Twas call-time, and the velvet scrims
Did shiver-shade along the fly;
All ghostly were the gaffer-grems,
And hushers hush-said slipping by.

Beware the Wingwraith, scene-struck child!
The flapful Wingwraith, soft and sly!
Beware the Snaptrap Trapdoor wild,
And shun the gelgobo-eye awry!

He gripped his crescent spanner keen,
The gaffer-wind did snick and sigh;
He sought the still-between of scene,
Where cues like crickets whisper by.

And while in muffish musing stood
Betwixt black legs and flats awry,
Came clitter-creep from curtain-wood,
The Wingwraith, sidewise spry.

Tap-thap! the boards beneath his boots,
Clat-clack! the pin-rail answered high;
Through haze of gels and gobo-fruits
He swung his crescent spanner high.

He snared it by its cue-tail thin,
He wrapped it fast in gaffer's tie;
Down-roped it to the sandbag bin—
The wing-winds whispered, "Aye! Aye!"

"O stagelet mine, thou brave-of-crew!
Come hither, strike-boy, spry!"
From prompty's perch the call went through,
"House out!"—a ringing cry.

'Twas afterglow; the leggy drapes
Did whisper-sweep the waiting ply;
All glimsy were the spike-tape shapes,
And soft the wings went softly by.

prompt: Create a poem about brown butter in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brown Butterwock

At supperglow the sizzle-sprites
Went skirling through the pan;
The milksnow broke in fleckish flights,
And browned to caramel.

Now mind, my sprout, the Butterwock—
That brunish, sputter-beast!
It leaps from foam with pop-and-shock,
And chars thy tender feast.

Take up thy whiskerblade so keen,
Thy spatularm of wood;
Set flame to low; keep watch between
The bubbles, as one should.

He lingered by the skillet's brim,
The stovetop hummed and purred;
The butter-blocks grew soft and slim,
And Foamsome Legions stirred.

Through froth and steam the Butterwock
Came flurry-bold and loud;
It clacked a popping spatter-clock
And threw a toasty cloud.

One swirl! another—swirl once more—
He danced the pan along;
He cooled the flame, he skimmed the shore,
Till rose brown-butter song.

He caught, between the fleck and foam,
The moment amber-brown;
He tamed the beast and drew it home—
Gold-dripping, drizzled down.

Have you now gentled Butterwock?
O whisker-jubilant hoorah!
Let breadlings sop, and herbs unlock
Its hazel-brown bouquet.

At supperglow the sizzle-sprites
Lie drowsy, brown, and done;
The panmouth hums in nutty bites,
And dinner's bravely won.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Creeple-Creep

'Twas murkle-morn, and glimmy groves
Did swurl and shamble in the shade;
The blither-boughs of knurly coves
Went mumfling down the glade.

"Beware the Creep, my tender sprout!
It pads where lampwicks fail to keep;
And shun the Sloom and Snither-Snout
That slubber through your sleep."

He took his chime-edge flitter-blade,
And gripped it by the knuckled steep;
Long time he weighed the thrummered shade
By willow’s whisper-deep.

And while he leaned by Thrumble Tree,
With breathing slow and deep,
There seeped from dark, so slinkingly,
The serry-sneaking Creep.

It wore the dusk about its fur,
Its smile a zipper-zagging seam;
No thunder-foot, no clatter-stir—
It slided like a dream.

One two! One two! Skritch-scratch it flashed,
The chime-edge sang a cheep;
He split the hush; the shadows dashed—
Down toppled there the Creep.

"And hast thou felled that whisper-thing?
O chiming bells that peep!
Come to my arms, my nimbleling!"
He laughed a tumbling leap.

'Twas murkle-morn; the glimmy groves
No longer shambled quite so deep;
And blither-boughs from knurly coves
Went waffling, freed of Creep.

prompt: Compose a poem on awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awlkin

In stitchlight dusk, the cobbler's stall
lay bristle-bent with scraps of sole;
The thimbers hummed a needlet fall,
and out there pried the whisper-awl.

"Mind, little sprout," the elder crooned,
"keep glove to grip and back to wall;
That peery-peery point has swooned
more hides than I can count at all.

It bores through boot and oxhide belt,
it sips the stars with gimlet drawl;
So pace with care and leather felt,
and dodge the prickle-path of Awl."

He gripped a lapstone, broad and square,
a stitch-shield cinched with waxen shawl;
With twined-up thread about his hair,
he went to meet the pricklet awl.

By solewood stump and peg-box row,
where lasts like lamplit toadstools sprawl,
it skirred and skittered, low then low—
a pinch, a peep, the peckish awl.

It jinked and jittered, bore on bore,
through seams of dusk it sought to crawl;
He feinted left with pegging cord
and thunked it with the lapstone’s maul.

He corked its nib with corken cap,
he spooled it tight in twizzle-thrall;
"Be still," he said, with thimble tap,
"no more you nip the night, you awl."

The benches chimed; boots heel-toe pranced;
wax-candles wept a golden fall;
They hung it high, all safe and chanced—
a trusty thing, a tamely awl.

In stitchlight calm, the cobbler's stall
slept sole to sole and heel to hall;
The thimbers dreamed of needle-fall,
and nothing pricked the dark at all.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Third-Rail Humblebrum

Gloom-glimmered were the tunnely tracts,
Where rivet-stars shed iron dew;
The third-rail hum, in humblebracts,
Went zizzle-thrum of seething blue.

“Shun, shun the third-rail’s hummelling—
That zappish stripe that sings!
And mind the snap-and-sputterling,
The bite that lightning brings!”

With griptight boots and muffler-mitt,
I paced the ballast plain;
My spark-proof staff went tunk-a-tit
Through soot and sleeper-grain.

And as I hushed by pillar-post,
The Humblebrum drew nigh—
It thrumbled through the tunnelmost,
An ozoned, whispery sigh.

I did not dance the crackleband
Nor test the yellow seam;
I tipped my cap with rubbered hand
And let it buzz and beam.

Back up the steps to Gramphy’s grin:
“That tune is sharp and sly—
The third-rail hum would snare you in;
I kept my shoon—and bye!”

Gloom-glimmered still the tunnely tracts,
While rivet-stars dripped iron dew;
The third-rail hum in humblebracts
Kept zizzle-thrumming blue.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about interference in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Crossphase

Gloam-o'-clock, the quiverwaves
went flimmerflam along the glade;
All frimsy bowed the fringe-born caves,
while antinodes unmade.

Beware the Interfizzle glare,
the crossphase clutch, the scattershock!
Shun peak-on-peak that traps the air,
and troughs that kink the clock.

He took his trusty fringefork blade;
long-time he sought the trouble-zone.
He lounged beside a slit-leaf shade
and mused in mutterbone.

And, burbling through the dappled haze,
the Interfizzle softly came,
with cresty-crest and quirking phase,
and cancel in its frame.

One step! two steps! peaks embraced—
flip-flash the fringefork hummed and sang!
Construck! Destruck! the pattern laced—
and all the night-bells rang.

He scooped the hush from where it lay,
and homeward strode through sodden dew;
The waves behind went meekly gray,
no longer two-on-two.

"And hast thou quelled the clatterphase?
Come hither—oh the joy we see!"
He twirled about in rimpled praise:
Huzzoodle! Yip-for-glee!

Gloam-o'-clock, the quiverwaves
lay smooth as silk along the glade;
No frimsy stirred in fringe-born caves—
the antinodes unmade.

prompt: Compose a poem on umbrella in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brollywoggle

It dribber-draped the gloaming street,
and gustlewhifflers gnyrd and groaned;
the puddle-pips went flit and fleet,
and shingles shushed and moaned.

Mind well the Dripdragoon, my sprout!
The Squalliwag with splashing jaws!
Shun mizzle, smear, and dampy doubt,
and clutch thy brolly by its claws.

He buckled up his umbrage stick—
the whalebone-ribbed, the button-bright—
its canopry went thrum and click
and mushroomed midnight-light.

Down drapper-lanes the Dripdragoon,
with guggle-gullet, sloshing, sped;
it slither-sang a drizzlemune
and leapt with puddle-treads.

Flip-flap! the canvas bloomed and boomed;
the ferrule jabbed the gustling snout;
the tappatappa drops were groomed
to run like riddles out.

He twirled the crook; the cloth carreened;
it gulped the gale; it held its ground;
the Dripdragoon unseamed, unpreened,
fell foamed and sprinkle-drowned.

He snapped it shut with clack and gleam,
and shouldered home through gleety air;
the rooflets chimed a tinnish dream,
the world was brolly-fair.

It dribber-draped no more the street;
the gustlewhifflers dozed and doffed;
the puddle-pips lay mild and sweet,
and chimney-sighs were soft.

poem:
The Quibble-Fair

By lumened lamps the tri-folds stood,

  the laser-pointer carved a streak;

  and stilled the calendar-beast's squeak.

"And hast thou quelled the Agendawock?
  O day of downsized dread and din!"
He jigged a jig around the clock,
  and dumped the markers in the bin.

  sat meek and musing round the table;

  and hum-lights dozed, more stable.

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Third-Rail Humdidoo

Deep under-tiles the tunnel smooled,
The third-rail thrummed a drumming hum;
The sleepers blinked, the ballast drooled,
And switch-frogs croaked ker-thrumperum.

“O hush your toes, my spraggle lad!
Beware the Third-Rail Humdidoo!
The spark-sprite bites when glary-glad,
And licks through leather, sock, and shoe!

“Shun neon serpents on the floor,
Shun gaps that grin their gribble-grins!
And mind the yellow whisper-shore
Where danger paints its warning-skins!”

He gripped a valiant brolly-rod,
He donned his rubbered boots so numb;
He sniffed the ozone—clack and nod—
And quested for the tremble-hum.

Just then, in drenchy gloom he froze,
The Hum came burbling under-sprung,
With zizzle-manes and crackle-jaws
That sang a buzzle on the tongue.

Flip-slap! through puddle-sheen he slid,
A nudgey jig on wary toes;
He kept the hum where hummin’s hid,
And let the fizz go by his nose.

Did he unmake the Hum in twain?
Nay—tempered it with thumb-on-thumb;
He learned its song, its copper-brain,
And marched in time with third-rail drum.

“O sprockled chum! O trolley joy!”
He bounded back in tunnel-glow;
“Come hear the murmur I employ—
It purrs beneath, yet bids us ‘No.’”

Deep under-tiles the tunnel smooled,
The third-rail thrummed its secret thrum;
All hush-and-spark the sleepers ruled,
And city hearts went hum hum hum.

The Pixelwraith (A Burn‑In Ballad)

prompt: Create a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Underpass Echo

’Twas drizzlum, and the rumble-bus
went ruckle ’neath the ribbed arcade;
all puddle-pale the sodiums,
and girders gargled shade.

“Beware the Underpass Echo, child!
The hollow-bell, the bumper-bang!
Beware the clank-clank Pylon-wild,
the bellowdrift and clang!”

He took his neon quarterstaff;
long time the murk foe-sought—
he lingered by graffitide graff
and muzzy-muttered thought.

And, as in buffer-brood he stood,
the Echo—boom and hush—
came lollop-looping undergird
with rebound, rebound, rush.

He spoke a word; it doubled thrice,
it tripled up the span;
it ricocheted like winter-ice
and back along him ran.

“Ha-hey!” he cried; with clitter-crack
the neon pole went through—
the tunnel chimed it back-a-back:
“Ha-HEY! Ha-hey!” times two.

He netted up the bellow-beast
in hush and rubbered tread,
and tire-drums dwindled, west to east—
its boomer-boom lay dead.

“And hast thou quelled the Underpass
that tosses talk awry?
Come hither, gleamish child, at last—
O lampesome hour! O sky!”

’Twas drizzlum, and the rumble-bus
went ruckle ’neath the ribbed arcade;
now puddle-pale the sodiums,
and quiet pooled in shade.

The Paperjammer

The crinkle-clutch, the buckle-bite!
Beware the sneaky Gatherfout,
And shun the Fuser Blight!"

His grabbly tongs, spare-springed of greed;

To brave the hungry feed.

Came scrunchling up the feedpath flume
And made the clutches numb.

Click-clack! Snap-snap! The spudger sang—
He teased the scroll from fuser maw;
The crumple-beast unluffed its tang,
Uncreased its wrinkled jaw.

"And hast thou quelled the Paperjam?
Come press me, bright and toner-blest!
O printsome day, O duplex-glam—
Our cogheart clacks its best!"

'Twas brizzletime; the tonershamps
Went whirgle-wrandle through the tray;
How trimly now the feeder stamps,
And clean the hours lay.

prompt: Compose a poem on déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Déjàwhirl

It was the gloaming-glim that spun,
And quibble-quabs went coil and coo;
The mirror-wind unstitched the sun,
And time made rings of déjà vu.

“Mind well,” said Gramfer, clockwise-bent,
“The loopish look, the known-too-new;
The tick that says, ‘We’ve met, we went,’
The sly, recurling déjà vu.”

He took his chrono-cleaving blade,
His maybe-remembering view;
He sought the place where moments braid,
To hunt the hushing déjà vu.

He rested by the second’s seam,
Beside a hushful palin-grove;
And thought two thoughts that felt a dream,
Like twins that knew the paths they wove.

And while in murrish mood he stood,
With double-sighted, niddle view—
Flip-flap! through twice-remembered wood
Came lolloping the déjà vu,

With backward eyes and forward feet,
It nodded, nodding: “Knew, I knew!”
It breathed a rhyme of stale and sweet,
And swam the air of déjà vu.

Swish-swash went blade and braided time,
Clip-clap the clocks like corkscrews flew;
He cut the knot of knells and rhyme,
And cleft the curling déjà vu.

He bore it limp and lasso-wound,
Its twice-seen eyes a dismal blue;
The wrinkled clocks uncreased their sound,
“They skip no more—the déjà vu.”

Now gloaming-glim returns to spin,
The quibble-quabs sleep two by two;
The mirror-wind folds up its skin,
And time unloops from déjà vu.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Bimmelboom Room

At hush-o’-clock the velvet hall
went thrimble-soft and clear;
The tinkletones and thrumble-drones
came swaying to the ear.

The lampwinks blinked on polished brass,
the cello-shadows grew;
In cabinets of ivoried keys
the sleepful hammers snoozed.

“Mind, mind the Clatterjack, my sprout,
and squeebled reeds that bite!
Beware the raspish Riddle-Rack
that nicks the ends of night!”

He took a trusty tuning fork,
a baton carved of yew;
By cymbal-stands he tiptoe-trod—
kept time, and courage too.

And as he hummed in heartbeat bars,
the Cacaphoon drew near,
with razzle-buzz and rumble-whirr
and discord in its sneer.

It clanged through cases, bowed the bows,
made harpsichords go pale;
Its breath was burr and bracken-brass,
its tail a dragging scale.

He raised his stick—tap, tip, ta-TAP—
and sliced the stillness through;
He flung a chord of seven lights
and bound the beast in blue.

The Cacaphoon unknotted, fell,
and puddled into calm;
It dwindled down to metronome
and ticked upon his palm.

He brought the quiet home again,
unlatched each waiting ear;
“O rapturous ring! Tra-la, hooray!”
the old bell-master cheered.

At hush-o’-clock the velvet hall
stayed thrimble-soft and clear;
The bimmelbooms and thrumble-drones
kept swaying to the ear.

prompt: Write a poem about layover bay in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Tarrygrin of Layover Bay

At Layover Bay, when time turns clay
And luggage-wheels go purring,
The flipflap signs sing clicky lines
While gate-lamps set to whirring.

Keep clear of Tarrygrin, O kin—
Its yawn unthreads your hurry;
Steer wide the Queue-cock, block-on-block,
And Laggertusk of worry.

He gripped his ticket-twirl and twine,
His carry-cane held steady;
He sought the dune of Gate-Four Moon
With pocket mints at ready.

And, as he sipped a fizzled sip
Beside the belt’s long belly,
Down loomed the drear Tarrygrin,
Its stare all gloam and jelly.

It breathed a hush of calendar,
Spilled minutes thick and surly;
The flipflap boards made rattle-chords—
The daylight sank too early.

He wheelied wide—his rollie cried—
He jigged a jangle-jolly;
His cane went clack through lag and slack
And thumped its drowsy lolling.

The Tarrygrin gave tarry-grin,
Then fizzed to foamy sputter;
It split a sack of ticking black—
Time fluttered mothy-clutter.

He palmed a shimmer-stamp of hours
To pace his onward scurry,
And trundled back to Layover Bay,
His shoes unsoaked by worry.

“Hurrah-ho-ho!” the bay-folk crowed,
In brabble-bright bravado;
“Hip-hip huzzap! Tip-top tip-tap!”
They danced a gate-stravado.

At Layover Bay the clocks grow spry
And spin instead of stalling;
The flipflap sings of ongo-things—
Departures bright and calling.

poem:
The Awlwhisper

It was knobble dusk in cobbler lane,
The prindle-pegs went clink in drawers;
All thrumble threads were tight with strain,
While gluepots hummed their gummy spores.

Old Stitcher spoke in wary drawl:
"Beware the pricklet’s sudden bite;
The snarlskin snaps, the pucker-maul—
Keep palm-guard tight, keep fingers light."

He palmed the beech-haft awl so trim,
The beeswax thread he twizzled thin;
A thumble-shield on leathered rim,
And set to stitch the shoon within.

He wited by the hidesome stack,
Where thickling cowborn panels sprawled;
The stitch-gap slept, a midnight crack,
Till tip-tip-tip the Awlthing called.

Tik-tak! tip-tap! it pecked the grain;
Through russet skin the bore went in;
The laces loved the neatling chain,
And hems lay flat with praiseful grin.

"O seam-delight!" he japed and yawed,
"Awonder awl, you prickling star!
Come dance the welt and welter awed,
We mend what sundered edges are."

And smuzzle-morn in cobbler lane,
The prindle-pegs still clinked in drawers;
All stitchy folk sang neat amain,
While gluepots dreamed their gummy spores.

The Creepsome Creep

the sumpy snaves did twirl and sweep;
All flimsy-faint the brundle vale,
and hush-stemmed hollows deep.

"Mind well the Creep, you sprindled sprout,
that creepsome Creep with clingy feet!
It sidles in by roundabout
and blurs what once was neat.

It buttons burr to every bough,
adds stitch to stitch and seam to seam;
It thickens 'why' and 'whether' now,
till straightways swerve and dream."

He raised his tally-tempered blade—
a never-yes-and-never-more;
He pegged the bounds with brazen braid
and paced the brambled floor.

with lurkle-laugh and oozy sweep,
it oozed and edged and made to grow—
the many-muzzled Creep.

Snick-snack the tally-blade went whirr,
the brazen braids drew taut with peep;
He cleft its clench and coil and burr,
and chopped it into sleep.

"O drammish noon!" the meadows peal,
"unrumple, roads, and leap!"
They danced the bounds with brassy zeal—
no more the things would creep.

The Desire-Path

poem:
The Whimblewade of Mornmist

At bellbird dawn the slimmish lanes
did sloom and smuddle in the vale;
All hushled were the hedge and stanes,
and lambfog trailed its pale.

“Beware the Sunspike, little sprout,
the glare that gashes gauze away!
Beware the briskly cockle-shout,
and shun the scaldsome day!”

his muffler warm, his whistling cup;
Through whimpled fields of milkish rain
he trundled fogward up.

The dewblink dripped; the gateposts loomed,
each footpath lost its knobbly way;
The willow-whistles gurled and boomed,
then hummed itself away.

And while he floundled, soft as moths
there purlt the Mornmist, swithe and sly;
It swaddled stiles and hedgerow-crofts
and smudged the brittle sky.

No clapper-wight with brashsome hue,
no scrailing gredge with gobbling latch;
Only the hush that foglings brew,
and morning’s tender thatch.

Then upupsprung the Sunspike’s blade—
a gildish grin through gloam and steam;
It riffled through the whimblewade
and unspun all the dream.

At bellbird dawn the slimmish lanes
did sloom and smuddle in the vale;
All hushled were the hedge and stanes,
till light unlaced the veil.

Thirdrailwocky

poem:
Ballad of the Bellows-Box

’Twas lenslight tide; the sprocketfolk
went whirr and wamble round the gate;
All halide-hushed the bellows spoke,
and leakish gleams lay late.

“Keep clear the Blinderflash, my sprout—
its bangy bloom, its sulfur flare!
Shun Shakerhand that jigs about,
and dust-drab motes that snare!

“Beware the Ghost of ISO Gray,
the Lurking Flare that guiles the glass!
The Blurblefoot that smears the day—
steer wide when windings pass!”

He wound the knurly crank with care,
he kissed the lens with sleeve and breath;
The focus-ring went roundy there
to beckon depth from death.

He waited where the lamplight weaves
by brick and budding rail of zinc;
Dark hushes nested in the eaves,
and street-time learned to blink.

Then out between the shade and shop
the Fleetingwisp came veer-and-sly:
with bokeh-bobbles tip-a-trop
and motor-mirrors in its eye.

Click-crack! the shutter clapped its beak—
a whirrish hymn, a velvet bite;
Through sprocket-teeth the silver streak
took captive of the light.

Back home beneath the safelight’s bruise
he swirled the trays that smell like rain;
Develop, stop, and fix—the redroom blues—
and ghosts came up in grain.

O lenslight tide! the sprocketfolk
still whirr and wamble round the gate;
In silver-sleeves the moments soak,
to wake again when light is late.
